item.title: Helldivers Film Adds Fast and Furious Director, It Writer
item.content:encoded:
Justin Lin, the director of several Fast and Furious films, has been announced as the director of the live-action Helldivers film. In addition, the writer of several horror films, like Annabelle and I,t wrote the script for the video game adaptation.

As one of PlayStation’s newer series, Helldivers didn’t seem to hit its stride until 2024, when it became a worldwide phenomenon. The multiplayer sci-fi shooter was a viral sensation and still is in some ways. With constant updates and a recent port to Xbox, Arrowhead Studios’ hit felt primed for Hollywood. In January 2025, it was announced that the game would be brought to film by Sony Pictures. Updates went silent for a bit until now, where it’s been revealed that a high-profile director and writer are attached.

Justin Lin Directing Helldivers Film for Sony Pictures, Written by Gary Dauberman

In an exclusive from The Hollywood Reporter, the outlet revealed that Justin Lin has joined the Helldivers film as director. He will be adapting from a script written by Gary Dauberman. While additional crew and casting have yet to be revealed, the report says that Lin plans to bring out the ‘humanity’ of the game with timely themes and a built-out world. It also seems like the story will revolve around a squad of elite Helldivers taking on various creatures and the Super Earth.

If you’ve watched any Fast and Furious movie from the 2010s, it’s likely been directed by Justin Lin. The filmmaker is a hit with action-film fans and a notable name in the genre. Currently, Lin is set to direct Keanu Reeves in BRZRKR and adapt One Punch Man into a film. For Gary Dauberman, the scribe has been behind some of horror’s recent hits like It (and its sequel, It Chapter Two), Annabelle, and Until Dawn. All that said, it’ll be interesting to see how Helldivers shapes up.

item.title: Splinter Cell Remake’s Director Has Returned to Ubisoft to Finish The Game
item.content:encoded:
Splinter Cell Remake director David Grivel has returned to Ubisoft to finish what he started in 2021.

Announced on his LinkedIn profile, David Grivel announced that he’s rejoining Ubisoft Toronto as the project’s Game Director for the Splinter Cell Remake.

The Splinter Cell Remake originally started development in 2021 under the codename ‘North’, with not much else being said on the game since. Insider Gaming exclusively reported in 2024 that the game is currently in development on the Snowdrop engine, with a tentative release date of 2026. It’s likely given the projects (and Ubisoft as a whole) issues that this release date is no longer accurate, but we will update our readers when we learn more.

Insider Gaming received footage of the project in early 2025, which showed Irving Lambert speaking to Sam Fisher in a superb cinematic. As it’s understood, the Splinter Cell Remake is a fully-fledged remake from the ground up, which will include being built around a modern audience from the ground up, rather than a simple graphic rehaul.

It’s understood that the game is in development for the PlayStation 5, Xbox Series S|X, and PC.

As for what Grivel’s return to the game means for the game’s immediate future is unclear, but the news that development continues on the game will be a warm welcome to those who were skeptical of the project’s future.

item.title: Best Co-Op Games for Family This Holiday Season 2025
item.content:encoded:
’Tis the holiday season, and what better way to spend your holiday than to spend your evenings playing co-op games with your family. During holiday times, everyone is at home, and it’s all around a great vibe. However, you can elevate that experience even further by introducing some cooperative games into the mix, which will test coordination and teamwork skills, and a little bit of chaos is always fun. 

This Insider Gaming guide will highlight the best co-op games that you can play with your family during this holiday, and the titles are spread across multiple platforms and genres, so there’s something for every type of family. 

At the same time, do check out Insider Gaming’s Holiday 2025 hub, which features the best deals that you can grab. 

Overcooked 2

Starting with the game that every family will enjoy, and some families might find themselves in the real world too, Overcooked 2. Overcooked 2 is a co-op game that focuses on cooking and waiting for customers. There are multiple maps, a variety of dishes to cook, and swarms of people to serve. This game is made for chaos and will definitely test your coordination skill,s as handling a kitchen is never easy. 

Mario Kart World

Mario Kart World is one of the more recent titles on the list, and the games in this series have always been top picks for family co-op fun. The latest entry in the series introduces some brand-new features, including a new open-world mode where players can drive freely and explore the world. The player limit has increased to 24 racers per race. And you can never go wrong with kart racing co-op games when playing with family.  

Super Mario Party Jamoboree

Super Mario Party Jamboree is the latest entry in the Mario Party series, which is a great all-around pick for not just family co-op games, but holiday multiplayer titles. It features over 110 mini-games you can play in 4-player co-op, along with different modes and choices. Here, rather than coordination and teamwork, some games will have you facing off against each other, bringing out everyone’s competitive spirit. 

Rocket League

Rocket League is a multiplayer title where you play football with cars. The title has now made a name for itself in the esports world, and it’s a lot of fun during casual co-op. You will have rocket-powered cars that you need to use to push the cars into the opponent’s net. It features local split-screen co-op, allowing all family members to dive into the adrenaline-fuelled fun. There are also a variety of games modes and some other sports to try out as well.

LEGO Star Wars: Skywalker Saga

Though LEGO Star Wars: Skywalker Saga only features 2-player co-op, you can still play it with your family, experiencing the story together, which is a plus. The game features all nine saga films with the iconic LEGO twist. There are also over 300 playable characters, over 100 vehicles, and 23 planets to explore. You get to be in the shoes of heroes and villains, and the trilogies can be played in any order.

LEGO: Marvel Superheroes 2

Similar to the previous title, LEGO: Marvel Superheroes 2 also offers only 2-player co-op, but it features a brand-new story families can experience together. You will get to embody superheroes and supervillains such as Guardians of the Galaxy, Spider-Man, Thor, Hulk, Black Panther, Captain Marvel, Doctor Strange, and Green Goblin. The game also features a world inspired by themes ranging from Ancient Egypt to The Old West, Sakaar, and New York City in 2099. 

Minecraft

You can never go wrong with Minecraft when thinking about family co-op games as a gift for holidays. Minecraft is one of the most popular games in the world, featuring a unique sandbox world where players can create anything they can imagine. Dive into this world with your family, show off your creations to each other, and explore this massive world till your heart’s content.

EA Sports FC 26

If your family is into sports such as football/soccer, then you can’t go wrong with a game like EA Sports FC 26. The game features almost all teams and leagues from around the world and unmatched co-op play, making it easy for players to get all their family members involved. It is one of the most realistic football/soccer simulation titles, and the latest instalment features more responsive dribbling, smarter AI positioning, sharper, more explosive movement, and much more.

It Takes Two

It Takes Two is a game that will take you and your family on one of the craziest journeys, where you experience the clashes between a couple who have been turned into dolls by a magic spell. It’s a strictly co-op game with connected character abilities for each level. Help each other while you face unexpected obstacles, gangs of crazy squirrels, and more. It won Game of the Year in 2021 and will surely keep you and your family entertained the whole time. 

Split Fiction

Split Fiction is a game from the same team behind It Takes Two. It features Mio and Zoe, two contrasting writers who have been trapped in their own stories and hooked to a machine designed to steal their creative ideas. One world is sci-fi, and the other is fantasy, featuring everything from challenging a monkey to a dance battle, fighting an evil kitty, and riding gravity bikes and sand sharks. 

Which of these games do you think is the best fit for some family co-op fun? Leave a comment down below or share your thoughts in Insider Gaming Discord.
